Classic_Features.text:
Classically presents around 6 to 18 months of age when foods containing gluten are introduced but can occur anytime
Chronic
diarrhea
Weight loss
Abdominal distension
Iron deficiency with or without
anemia
Aphthous stomatitis
Short stature
High aminotransferase levels
Chronic fatigue
Reduced bone mineral density
Vitamin D deficiency

Atypical_Features.text:
Few or no gastrointestinal symptoms
Older children or adults
Dermatitis herpetiformis
Gluten Ataxia

Silent_or_Asymptomatic_From.text:
Patients have no symptoms
Diagnosed based on serology of histology
Found in patients with strong family history of disease, autoimmune disorders, chromosomal disorders (
Down syndrome
)

Refractory_Form.text: Persistent or recurrent symptoms or villous atrophy despite gluten free diet for 12 months

Celiac_Crisis.text:
Life threatening
Often observed after a general immune stimulus such as surgery or infection
Mostly observed in children
Severe diarrhea
Hypoproteinemia
Metabolic and
electrolyte disturbances

Complications_from_untreated_disease[1][.text:
Osteoporosis
Impaired splenic function
Infertility
Recurrent
abortion
Ulcerative jejunoileitis
Enteropathy-associated intestinal T-cell
lymphoma
Adenocarcinoma of the jejunum
Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
Vitamin deficiencies

Chronic diarrhea

Lactose intolerance
Chronic pancreatitis
Microscopic colitis
Inflammatory bowel disease
Non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS)
Wheat allergy
Vitamin or mineral deficiency

Evaluation.text:
Rule out emergent causes of
abdominal pain
such as
appendicitis
,
small bowel obstruction
,
bowel perforation
, etc.
Depending on presentation, chemistry panel and/or abdominal imaging may be appropriate in the emergency department setting

Celiac_Crisis[4]_2.text:
History and physical
Assessment of volume status
CBC to look for evidence of iron deficiency anemia
CMP
VBG
Lactic acid

tables.Signs of severe dehydration including: h: Abnormal electrolytes including: hyper/hyponatremia, hypocalcemia, hypokalemia or hypomagnesemia

tables.Comments: Screening test in patients with IgA deficiency

Uncomplicated_Celiac_disease.text:
Avoid wheat, rye, barley which all contain gluten
Possible benefit to avoiding large amounts of Oats
IV fluids if necessary

Celiac_Crisis[4]_3.text:
Fluid resuscitation
Oral or IV
steroids
Supplemental nutrition
Electrolyte repletion
Gluten free diet
